headline: Lawsuit claims the Washington Post wrongfully bullied and targeted Nick Sandmann
subHeadline: The media made tons off of Covington Catholic High School student Nick Sandmann. Why shouldn't he get a piece of the action?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.sentences: Hi, I'm Greg Gutfeld with Emily Compagno, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and she wants tripped on a molecule, Dana Perino. “The Five.” Nick Sandmann, the smiling target of the infamous Covington smear is suing the Washington Post for 250 million bucks for leading the media mob. Can't say I blame him because the story isn't about Covington but those who covered it, not to mention all the money they made off that smear.  This case, along with Kavanaugh and Smollett and a hundred others, need to be a journalism course, one that reveals how echo chamber media gins up outrage, protects narrative and steers social media into a frenzy. We blame twitter, but twitter is just a wall the media throw stuff at to see what sticks.  If it sticks you make a lot of money or use it to build the reputations of some left-wing hacks. Nick's lawsuit means that in the future some dope can't brag to the Pulitzer committee that he broke the Covington story.  Remember the Clarence Thomas hearings and how that turned many liberals like Andrew Breitbart into fire-breathing conservatives? Sometimes a show trial reveals more than you think. Feinstein traded her reputation for a shot at Kavanaugh. Since 2016, those epiphany moments like Covington have piled up. In mere months, we've seen three major media fails. There are others. But there's only one persistent culprit at the crime scene, the mainstream media. Journalists who are writing for other journalists, hoping to get a better job, a book deal, a prize, a minute on TV.  And the motivating factor behind the machine, conflict. Conflict leads to eyeballs, which leads to clicks, which leads to money. Yeah, the media made tons off Covington, so why shouldn't the kid get a piece of the action? After all, without poor Nick, some of us would have to work for a living. So, Jesse, I have the brain room to do some research. Did you know --

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.sentences: What's my move?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Don't go burning up the brain room, all right? They're busy with my stuff.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Did you know that the Washington Post digital ad revenue for 2017 was a solid nine figures. That's over a $100 million. So that's how they make it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, from cells --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- hate and division cells.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I did enjoy reading the Washington Post report about how the Washington Post is bad because they got sued. That was fun. I also don't think it matters whether they win this lawsuit. This is just a big blow to fake news because right now every newsroom and all the executives -- this is coming from the top down, they're telling the editors and the reporters, do not shoot first and ask questions later.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's better to be late and right than first and wrong, because right now they're facing ruinous lawsuits. And it takes the penalty of financial hit for them to change their behavior because they're not policing themselves. You pointed out there's -- fake news is getting worse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So the only thing to do is hold them account financially. And I like watching the media being held to account because they like to hold other people account --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Like us.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Like us. And they never, ever have to look inwards, so this is a good thing.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.sentences: I hate to blow things up for you, but I mean you're so deep in the Trump bunker. Sometimes I think I've got to help Jesse out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: If I have a bunker, I'm not letting you in, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I hope I'm not in it, brother. I never want to get in that bunker because I'd be buried. Let me just tell you something, one, reporters, if opinion and somebody's opinion about Nick is now the subject of a lawsuit --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Not opinion, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- imagine what you would be up against, Jesse. You'll be in bed --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: With my smirk too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Jesse is never on twitter. You never on twitter.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It doesn't matter.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, but that's how it starts.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, you know what, but it wasn't the Washington Post, it wasn't NBC, wasn't any media outlet. This was started by a website that was intending to somehow divide the American people --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The Washington Post didn't do --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, Juan, Juan, but the Washington Post, they have to do due diligence. They have to fact-check. They have to check both sides and they have to investigate. Read the lawsuit, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They didn't call the other side. They didn't investigate the video. They kept on printing malicious smears of this guy about things that never happened. He never chanted anything derogatory. He never said build the wall, never said anything racist, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what, you are deep into a political tribal argument. The fact is here, this is --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- lawsuit. It should be dismissed. It's really an insult. But I will say this, is part of an attack on the press that we are seeing --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Any time you criticize the press --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no, no, give me a shot.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You can't be criticized.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, give me a shot. Because what do we see today, President Trump is saying the New York Times is the enemy of the people. Why? Because the New York Times did a story that said he asked the acting attorney general to appoint --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Can we stick to the story?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- that's what's going on here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Emily is a lawyer. Emily, tell me about what you think -- this case, 250 million, too much or not enough?

utterances.speaker: EMILY COMPAGNO, HOST
utterances.sentences: Well, the reason that they are seeking 250 million is because that's the amount that they purchase the Washington Post for in 2013. So I kinda -- I like that homage. I will say, Juan, to your point just now that -- I think that's exactly the -- unfortunately, invalid argument that is being made which is pointing to the president's rhetoric in defense of this. That's exactly the point the lawsuit makes. And to answer your question --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wait, explain what you just said.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: What matters -- or the heart of the lawsuit is whether WAPO negligently publish this information in reckless disregard of the actual truth or did they actually have malice. If it's a private --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: How do you prove that?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Here me out. The fact that -- for example, in the lawsuit it details that there were seven articles and three tweets and it listed all of the headlines and it listed the 13 million followers on twitter -- that implication process it is what is reasonably foreseeable.  And that lawsuit is basically saying, look, you -- you know, may be in the first time if you repeat a headline, that's one thing. But there were multiple -- multiple things where you are characterizing this minor child at the time in an externally derogatory way and it wasn't --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Emily, he was in the news. He had -- in fact --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, they made him the news.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Emily, he attended a March for Life rally. He was in a public place at the Lincoln Memorial. He was engaged in the expression of his opinions and his position and it was covered. In addition to --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Before we go to break --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: They're not just going after the Washington Post. They're going after CNN. They're going after NBC --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Juan --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dana, how are you?

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.sentences: I'm good. I'm enjoying listening to the conversation. A couple of things --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- this lawsuit will probably be dismissed upon the first hearing. The first motion to dismiss, I think the judge might rules that way. But are they making a good point? Yes. And it gets to a broader one which we've talked about this before, which is when, for example, a media company -- you've said digital ad sales?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So the other thing that they're getting out of that is your data, right? So what you're looking at, what you buy, what restaurants you're going to go to, all of that stuff.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And the question has been should you get a piece of that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Is that -- do you own some of that? So then -- the bigger picture point on this --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I get it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- is do you own your conflict?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Exactly, that is the genius moment of this show. We -- if you're an object in this conflict, you're the actor.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wait --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You deserve a role. You deserve a payment for the role.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Is that mean I have to pay people that were in Watters' World?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, no.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: That's the European view of it, right? And that's where we conflict is that, that. There the agent, the actor owns the data and here we don't. But I agree also that larger point that at what point do we hold accountable the media outlets that are literally, via the public mob, capitalizing on it and then ruining reputations forever.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So what do you do about Donald Trump today? He says go get them, Nick, because much like --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, that's terrible.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- Greg and Jesse, he's cheering them on because he sees this as evidence that the media is after him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I want to check. I want to -- no, my whole thing has always been the same. I believe that this is a consensus media in which the profit model is conflict and you've got to put a check on it. To me it doesn't matter if he gets money. You've just got to make them think. I just want -- all America wants is -- they just want the media to think before they shoot. Think before you shoot.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Where did the tape come from, Greg? Where the tape come from? Where did it come from? Mainstream media --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The Washington Post push this thing out --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You guys in the mainstream media didn't edit it, Juan. You guys took some random B.S. -- you took random B.S. and you spit it out there and put a bunch of lies in it. That's what you did.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think conservative websites that spread conspiracy theories are far more prevalent than anything --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I look forward to that research coming before me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's not the point. The point is you guys blew it and then you won't admit --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, there you go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right, Joe Biden, you remember him, is reportedly close to getting in to the 2020 race, but could Bernie spoil the party? Plus, Jussie Smollett's lawyers -- I don't know, I've just change -- are meeting with prosecutors. Breaking details ahead.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The 2020 Democratic field getting even more crowded. Joe Biden reportedly, quote, 90 percent there, on announcing a White House run, but he may have some serious competition. That's because Bernie Sanders blowing away the field in first-day fund-raising. The socialist Democratic senator took in nearly $6 million in the first 24 hours after he jumped into the race. So, can Biden top Sanders in the more progressive candidates if he does decide to run? Dana, apparently there's a push -- I've read an article today says all the Democrats want to be identified as liberals and progressives. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, knock yourselves out and then we'll see. I mean, that makes for a great contest going into 2020 --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's so violent.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I feel a couple of things about this. Biden, I believe that he has time to get in. I don't think he needs to rush. And people are really pushing him to get in because they want to get this underway. They want --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He's biding his time, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He's biding his time, thank you. And he's holding back fund- raising for the others because -- but, if you think about it, why would he get in right now? He has the highest name I.D. He can wait. Let these other guys fight it out for a little bit, see where they're all going to land.  Donald Trump didn't get into the primary until June of 2015. I don't think that Biden has to make a decision by next week. I think that's an artificial deadline. Bernie and Biden came in today at one and two in the New Hampshire poll, mostly that's about name I.D. When it comes to Bernie and the money, raising $6 million in 24 hours is a big deal, like that's a lot. But here's the more important thing, it's all grassroots small dollar money, so he has a network that he can go back to over and over again that these others don't, and that includes Joe Biden.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: By the way, so the announcement video that he put out broke all kinds of records, 5.4 million --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I mean, that's because Jesse watched it 3.7 million times.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Over and over again.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Emily, so we're talking and thinking about, gee, you know, when you look at the polls it's always Joe Biden is the clear leader, but there's an interesting distinction, if you look -- if the poll offers you names, then they pick Biden. But if you say, hey, you undecided or will you volunteer name, guess what? Biden is very close, like 9 percent for Biden, 8 percent for Harris. So what does this tell you?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: That's interesting. I think what it tells me is that Harris -- there was a bit of skepticism that I saw coming more from the east coast and those of us from the west coast really had high name recognition for her. She's a significant following and impact and awareness there in the west coast that I think the other half of the nation didn't see. And just to your point about the network, I think what's so interesting about Bernie Sanders is that, you know, he will always be that leader and the first guy of the socialist movement and whatever, and people will just gather behind him. And even if, intellectually, we're not sure how much runway is ahead, his followers think that it's limitless. And with that super delegate that rule now in the DNC, I think that he will be a formidable opponent to Biden regardless if he takes his time and has that name recognition. Bernie Sanders might really make some changes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: By the way, Jesse, so President Trump had something to say about Bernie's success. He said, crazy Bernie, he missed his time, indicating he should have run -- should have had the opportunity to run against him in 2016. But then Bernie fired back, maybe this is different. Maybe this why people like Bernie, he said the only crazy is the president who's racist, sexist, xenophobic, and a fraud.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK, well done, crazy Bernie. Who cares?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think what's happening is people slept on Bernie. People forgot about Bernie. And Bernie comes out and raises more money in four hours than Kamala Harris raise in 24, and people start looking around and saying, oh, my God, this guy has got the small donor network, almost as good as Trump, raised 200 million last cycle, and he could be a serious threat.  Remember, Bernie is fluent in socialism. It's like his native tongue. He doesn't have to speak in codes. He literally wired the socialism code. He's not a pretender. He's the real deal. He was cool before socialism was cool. So I could see Bernie getting the most applause at the debates, raising the most amount of money and winning Iowa. And all of a sudden, the kingmakers of the Democratic Party are thinking of themselves, oh, my God, we have a serious problem again on our hands, and they're going to have to kneecap this guy again.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But they've tried to because he will have to register as a Democrat in order to win this time around. That's their new rule.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And by the way --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Is he going to break the rule?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- to Jesse's point, I just want to back up something you've said, 70 percent of Democrats under 30 voted for Bernie Sanders in 2016.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He's got the grassroots.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Let me tackle Biden and then Bernie, OK? Biden, he has a problem in the intersectional beauty pageant. He's old, white and male. He won't even get Ms. Congeniality at that rate. He should market himself as the first trans-president, hair transplant.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, gosh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And see that -- actually help. Now, Bernie, I'm glad Bernie's running because I think people do need a lesson about socialism and what it's doing to this country because the people that like Bernie don't realize how socialism has destroyed them. When the government pays for things, I.E., making them free, it leads to a horrific death. It artificially inflates prices. So when I'm talking about these -- who's being hurt most it's students with student loan debt. The student loan bubble is due to artificially inflated prices because you can get these loans. So that's what's got to be tied. You've got to teach kids that socialism ruins your life. It bankrupted you by artificially inflating the price of college. They can raise the tuition because of there are loans that could cover it. And then you're stuck with it and these greedy administrators are laughing all the way to the bank while you basically mortgage your life. That's socialism.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And you know they've just raised rates -- college rates -- college tuitions in in Vermont.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: At the university where Bernie Sanders' wife works. And also, their daughter taught a woodcutting class there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yep, it costs $383,000.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: To take the course?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: To get the whole -- to get the class all organized.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I want to just end by telling you that a poll asked people if you don't care about the issues but you care who can beat Trump, who's your pick? And 56 percent chose Joe Biden.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What a dumb poll.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: We have -- I'll take that to the bank. We have brand-new video reportedly showing the brothers in the Jussie Smollett case buying the materials that were used in the attack. That breaking new development next on “The Five.”

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Fox News alert, major new developments in the Jussie Smollett investigation. Chicago police have announced Smollett is officially a suspect in a criminal investigation for filing a false report.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Meanwhile, stunning new surveillance video obtained by CBS Chicago has surfaced reportedly showing two brothers at the center of the case buying what is believed to be a red hat and ski mask the day before the attack. This as prosecutors in Chicago are meeting with Smollett's lawyers. Mike Tobin, outside criminal court in Chicago with the latest. Mike?

utterances.speaker: MIKE TOBIN, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: this is all happening very fast and furious. You've just mentioned moments ago, the chief communications officer Anthony Guglielmi for the Chicago PD says that Jussie Smollett is now a suspect for a class four felony, falsifying a police report. We know that's a punishable by a maximum of three years. This while we have just learned from people who have been staking out the grand jury room on the fourth floor that the Osundairo brothers have gone back inside for round two inside the grand jury room, seemed to be kind of a false start with the grand jury yesterday. And again, the people who have been staking out the grand jury room say the brothers are inside at this moment as the case moves forward. On a day when we now have surveillance video coming to us from WBBM channel two here in Chicago, and this is security video from what we're told by employees at the Crafty Beaver is inside of their store, and it shows these individuals buying things like ski masks, what looks to be a red hat. We know of the inventory that was taken from the apartment where the Osundairo brothers were staying here in Chicago. One of the items on that inventory is a red hat, and that could have very well played a role in what is now shaping up more and more to have been a hoax attack in this case. So we now have Jussie Smollett, he's been listed as a suspect in this case officially according to the chief communications officer. This long- standing request for police to have a conversation with Smollett, that has not been realized. He never showed up for this follow-up interview. We have some information that lawyers for Smollett and police met today. The Sun Times has indicated that that meeting is going on right now. The clarification we have through the official police channels is that meeting happened this morning but never the conversation that they want to have with Smollett. Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Thanks a lot, Mike. All right, Emily, I believe the prosecutors have to go hard on this class four felony. They have to prosecute him. They can't just drop this because if they don't go hard on him, it's going to send a message that you can get away with this stuff and not pay a price.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yeah, absolutely. And you know there's prosecutorial discretion there in Illinois. They could have proceed it as a misdemeanor. They have the option for filling a false police --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They've prompt it up.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Exactly. So that speaks for itself right there. And you know those crimes are classified as they're crimes against public justice. It's taken really seriously because it is. There should absolutely be zero tolerance for and a strong message sent when people do this, especially in the level of fabrication that, you know, we are seeing, allegedly, when into this. That level of pro-action and creating this entire dramatic thing and roping in other people, I mean, it's -- yes, it's absolutely should have dire consequences, for sure.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, Mike Tobin still with us, I think. Mike? Mike, are you there? Well, maybe not.

utterances.speaker: TOBIN
utterances.sentences: I'm here.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, Mike. So, Mike, as I understand it, there was pressure being put to bring Smollett into the grand jury. But today, apparently, his lawyers spoke to the Cook County attorneys and they said OK, he doesn't have to come in. I wonder, is he sick? What was the mitigating factor or the sculpting factor that would lead Cook County officials to say he didn't have to appear before the grand jury?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Because they can do it without him.

utterances.speaker: TOBIN
utterances.sentences: I think it's more of a situation where you have -- you get this with the legal community that any good lawyer, if he's going to insist that he did nothing wrong, any good lawyer is going to tell them don't go in for that meeting because all they're going to want to do in the course of that meeting is catch him in a lie. And all indications are that something is amiss in this case. So I don't know if it's necessary exculpatory evidence that gets involved in that, but when you have this sudden halt to the process yesterday, and the Cook County state attorney Kim Fox, recusing yourself, you may have some kind of evidence that was introduced yesterday. And it should be noted that The Tribune is running a report right now saying the reason she has suddenly recuse herself is because she got pretty close with the family during the initial stages, when everyone thought that Jussie Smollett was the victim of a hate crime.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Mike. Dana, you know what's crazy about this whole thing and how sociopathic this guy Smollett is? If they had arrested two innocent guys, he would have said, yeah, these are the guys and he would have been OK with putting away innocent men.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yeah. Did you watch “The Five” yesterday?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I made that point.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, you did? Great minds think alike, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And also, this is -- I have a question. These guys work in television. They work on a very successful show, Empire. They obviously probably watch a lot of TV, they've probably watched a lot of movies, like, do they not think for one second that there's going to be a video camera where -- in the hardware store? Did they not think that there's not going to be -- like, all of these questions? I just feel like he was willing to put other people away for something that also was like very poorly done.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: As for as the hoax goes, he must have just truly believed that the media was just going to believe every word that he said and then he was going to be protected from that. But I'm glad the police are pursuing it. I think it's good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, great actor, terrible criminal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, you know I don't see how what he did is not considered a hate crime, because it actually is - would have hurt a group of people. And to your point--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All Trump supporter.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Millions of Americans.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh! My God. Is that what this is all about.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Bear with me, Juan. I listen to you. This is a hate crime. And to your point, that's despicable that he would let two people go to jail. utterances.sentences: All right. This is an eCOPO Camaro Concept car. It's a battery powered drag racing special and 700 horsepower and 600-foot pound of torche.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: How much torque?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: 600-foot pound.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's a lot of torque.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, and it's all fueled by coal.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Anyway, 134 miles per hour. I'm still a Ford girl myself. You guys know I love my Mach 1, but I appreciated that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There is your Mach 1.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Here it is.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Cool.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Emily, you're a rider anyway.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wow, nice wheels.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: You've seen that husky photo before of Duchess.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm tired of it frankly and Emily, I'm tired of you. You make me sick Set your DVRs. utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.utterance: Hi, I'm Greg Gutfeld with Emily Compagno, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and she wants tripped on a molecule, Dana Perino. “The Five.” Nick Sandmann, the smiling target of the infamous Covington smear is suing the Washington Post for 250 million bucks for leading the media mob. Can't say I blame him because the story isn't about Covington but those who covered it, not to mention all the money they made off that smear. This case, along with Kavanaugh and Smollett and a hundred others, need to be a journalism course, one that reveals how echo chamber media gins up outrage, protects narrative and steers social media into a frenzy. We blame twitter, but twitter is just a wall the media throw stuff at to see what sticks. If it sticks you make a lot of money or use it to build the reputations of some left-wing hacks. Nick's lawsuit means that in the future some dope can't brag to the Pulitzer committee that he broke the Covington story. Remember the Clarence Thomas hearings and how that turned many liberals like Andrew Breitbart into fire-breathing conservatives? Sometimes a show trial reveals more than you think. Feinstein traded her reputation for a shot at Kavanaugh. Since 2016, those epiphany moments like Covington have piled up. In mere months, we've seen three major media fails. There are others. But there's only one persistent culprit at the crime scene, the mainstream media. Journalists who are writing for other journalists, hoping to get a better job, a book deal, a prize, a minute on TV. And the motivating factor behind the machine, conflict. Conflict leads to eyeballs, which leads to clicks, which leads to money. Yeah, the media made tons off Covington, so why shouldn't the kid get a piece of the action? After all, without poor Nick, some of us would have to work for a living. So, Jesse, I have the brain room to do some research. Did you know --

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.utterance: What's my move?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Don't go burning up the brain room, all right? They're busy with my stuff.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Did you know that the Washington Post digital ad revenue for 2017 was a solid nine figures. That's over a $100 million. So that's how they make it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, from cells --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- hate and division cells.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I did enjoy reading the Washington Post report about how the Washington Post is bad because they got sued. That was fun. I also don't think it matters whether they win this lawsuit. This is just a big blow to fake news because right now every newsroom and all the executives -- this is coming from the top down, they're telling the editors and the reporters, do not shoot first and ask questions later.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's better to be late and right than first and wrong, because right now they're facing ruinous lawsuits. And it takes the penalty of financial hit for them to change their behavior because they're not policing themselves. You pointed out there's -- fake news is getting worse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So the only thing to do is hold them account financially. And I like watching the media being held to account because they like to hold other people account --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Like us.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Like us. And they never, ever have to look inwards, so this is a good thing.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.utterance: I hate to blow things up for you, but I mean you're so deep in the Trump bunker. Sometimes I think I've got to help Jesse out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: If I have a bunker, I'm not letting you in, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I hope I'm not in it, brother. I never want to get in that bunker because I'd be buried. Let me just tell you something, one, reporters, if opinion and somebody's opinion about Nick is now the subject of a lawsuit --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not opinion, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- imagine what you would be up against, Jesse. You'll be in bed --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: With my smirk too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jesse is never on twitter. You never on twitter.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It doesn't matter.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, but that's how it starts.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, you know what, but it wasn't the Washington Post, it wasn't NBC, wasn't any media outlet. This was started by a website that was intending to somehow divide the American people --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The Washington Post didn't do --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, Juan, Juan, but the Washington Post, they have to do due diligence. They have to fact-check. They have to check both sides and they have to investigate. Read the lawsuit, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They didn't call the other side. They didn't investigate the video. They kept on printing malicious smears of this guy about things that never happened. He never chanted anything derogatory. He never said build the wall, never said anything racist, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what, you are deep into a political tribal argument. The fact is here, this is --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- lawsuit. It should be dismissed. It's really an insult. But I will say this, is part of an attack on the press that we are seeing --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Any time you criticize the press --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, give me a shot.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You can't be criticized.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, give me a shot. Because what do we see today, President Trump is saying the New York Times is the enemy of the people. Why? Because the New York Times did a story that said he asked the acting attorney general to appoint --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Can we stick to the story?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- that's what's going on here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Emily is a lawyer. Emily, tell me about what you think -- this case, 250 million, too much or not enough?

utterances.speaker: EMILY COMPAGNO, HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, the reason that they are seeking 250 million is because that's the amount that they purchase the Washington Post for in 2013. So I kinda -- I like that homage. I will say, Juan, to your point just now that -- I think that's exactly the -- unfortunately, invalid argument that is being made which is pointing to the president's rhetoric in defense of this. That's exactly the point the lawsuit makes. And to answer your question --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait, explain what you just said.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: What matters -- or the heart of the lawsuit is whether WAPO negligently publish this information in reckless disregard of the actual truth or did they actually have malice. If it's a private --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: How do you prove that?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Here me out. The fact that -- for example, in the lawsuit it details that there were seven articles and three tweets and it listed all of the headlines and it listed the 13 million followers on twitter -- that implication process it is what is reasonably foreseeable. And that lawsuit is basically saying, look, you -- you know, may be in the first time if you repeat a headline, that's one thing. But there were multiple -- multiple things where you are characterizing this minor child at the time in an externally derogatory way and it wasn't --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Emily, he was in the news. He had -- in fact --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, they made him the news.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Emily, he attended a March for Life rally. He was in a public place at the Lincoln Memorial. He was engaged in the expression of his opinions and his position and it was covered. In addition to --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Before we go to break --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They're not just going after the Washington Post. They're going after CNN. They're going after NBC --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dana, how are you?

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.utterance: I'm good. I'm enjoying listening to the conversation. A couple of things --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- this lawsuit will probably be dismissed upon the first hearing. The first motion to dismiss, I think the judge might rules that way. But are they making a good point? Yes. And it gets to a broader one which we've talked about this before, which is when, for example, a media company -- you've said digital ad sales?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So the other thing that they're getting out of that is your data, right? So what you're looking at, what you buy, what restaurants you're going to go to, all of that stuff.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And the question has been should you get a piece of that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Is that -- do you own some of that? So then -- the bigger picture point on this --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I get it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- is do you own your conflict?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly, that is the genius moment of this show. We -- if you're an object in this conflict, you're the actor.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wait --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You deserve a role. You deserve a payment for the role.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is that mean I have to pay people that were in Watters' World?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, no.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: That's the European view of it, right? And that's where we conflict is that, that. There the agent, the actor owns the data and here we don't. But I agree also that larger point that at what point do we hold accountable the media outlets that are literally, via the public mob, capitalizing on it and then ruining reputations forever.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So what do you do about Donald Trump today? He says go get them, Nick, because much like --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, that's terrible.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- Greg and Jesse, he's cheering them on because he sees this as evidence that the media is after him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I want to check. I want to -- no, my whole thing has always been the same. I believe that this is a consensus media in which the profit model is conflict and you've got to put a check on it. To me it doesn't matter if he gets money. You've just got to make them think. I just want -- all America wants is -- they just want the media to think before they shoot. Think before you shoot.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Where did the tape come from, Greg? Where the tape come from? Where did it come from? Mainstream media --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The Washington Post push this thing out --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You guys in the mainstream media didn't edit it, Juan. You guys took some random B.S. -- you took random B.S. and you spit it out there and put a bunch of lies in it. That's what you did.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think conservative websites that spread conspiracy theories are far more prevalent than anything --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I look forward to that research coming before me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's not the point. The point is you guys blew it and then you won't admit --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, there you go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, Joe Biden, you remember him, is reportedly close to getting in to the 2020 race, but could Bernie spoil the party? Plus, Jussie Smollett's lawyers -- I don't know, I've just change -- are meeting with prosecutors. Breaking details ahead.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The 2020 Democratic field getting even more crowded. Joe Biden reportedly, quote, 90 percent there, on announcing a White House run, but he may have some serious competition. That's because Bernie Sanders blowing away the field in first-day fund-raising. The socialist Democratic senator took in nearly $6 million in the first 24 hours after he jumped into the race. So, can Biden top Sanders in the more progressive candidates if he does decide to run? Dana, apparently there's a push -- I've read an article today says all the Democrats want to be identified as liberals and progressives. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, knock yourselves out and then we'll see. I mean, that makes for a great contest going into 2020 --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's so violent.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I feel a couple of things about this. Biden, I believe that he has time to get in. I don't think he needs to rush. And people are really pushing him to get in because they want to get this underway. They want --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's biding his time, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He's biding his time, thank you. And he's holding back fund- raising for the others because -- but, if you think about it, why would he get in right now? He has the highest name I.D. He can wait. Let these other guys fight it out for a little bit, see where they're all going to land. Donald Trump didn't get into the primary until June of 2015. I don't think that Biden has to make a decision by next week. I think that's an artificial deadline. Bernie and Biden came in today at one and two in the New Hampshire poll, mostly that's about name I.D. When it comes to Bernie and the money, raising $6 million in 24 hours is a big deal, like that's a lot. But here's the more important thing, it's all grassroots small dollar money, so he has a network that he can go back to over and over again that these others don't, and that includes Joe Biden.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: By the way, so the announcement video that he put out broke all kinds of records, 5.4 million --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean, that's because Jesse watched it 3.7 million times.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Over and over again.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Emily, so we're talking and thinking about, gee, you know, when you look at the polls it's always Joe Biden is the clear leader, but there's an interesting distinction, if you look -- if the poll offers you names, then they pick Biden. But if you say, hey, you undecided or will you volunteer name, guess what? Biden is very close, like 9 percent for Biden, 8 percent for Harris. So what does this tell you?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: That's interesting. I think what it tells me is that Harris -- there was a bit of skepticism that I saw coming more from the east coast and those of us from the west coast really had high name recognition for her. She's a significant following and impact and awareness there in the west coast that I think the other half of the nation didn't see. And just to your point about the network, I think what's so interesting about Bernie Sanders is that, you know, he will always be that leader and the first guy of the socialist movement and whatever, and people will just gather behind him. And even if, intellectually, we're not sure how much runway is ahead, his followers think that it's limitless. And with that super delegate that rule now in the DNC, I think that he will be a formidable opponent to Biden regardless if he takes his time and has that name recognition. Bernie Sanders might really make some changes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: By the way, Jesse, so President Trump had something to say about Bernie's success. He said, crazy Bernie, he missed his time, indicating he should have run -- should have had the opportunity to run against him in 2016. But then Bernie fired back, maybe this is different. Maybe this why people like Bernie, he said the only crazy is the president who's racist, sexist, xenophobic, and a fraud.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, well done, crazy Bernie. Who cares?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think what's happening is people slept on Bernie. People forgot about Bernie. And Bernie comes out and raises more money in four hours than Kamala Harris raise in 24, and people start looking around and saying, oh, my God, this guy has got the small donor network, almost as good as Trump, raised 200 million last cycle, and he could be a serious threat. Remember, Bernie is fluent in socialism. It's like his native tongue. He doesn't have to speak in codes. He literally wired the socialism code. He's not a pretender. He's the real deal. He was cool before socialism was cool. So I could see Bernie getting the most applause at the debates, raising the most amount of money and winning Iowa. And all of a sudden, the kingmakers of the Democratic Party are thinking of themselves, oh, my God, we have a serious problem again on our hands, and they're going to have to kneecap this guy again.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But they've tried to because he will have to register as a Democrat in order to win this time around. That's their new rule.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And by the way --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is he going to break the rule?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- to Jesse's point, I just want to back up something you've said, 70 percent of Democrats under 30 voted for Bernie Sanders in 2016.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's got the grassroots.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Let me tackle Biden and then Bernie, OK? Biden, he has a problem in the intersectional beauty pageant. He's old, white and male. He won't even get Ms. Congeniality at that rate. He should market himself as the first trans-president, hair transplant.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, gosh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And see that -- actually help. Now, Bernie, I'm glad Bernie's running because I think people do need a lesson about socialism and what it's doing to this country because the people that like Bernie don't realize how socialism has destroyed them. When the government pays for things, I.E., making them free, it leads to a horrific death. It artificially inflates prices. So when I'm talking about these -- who's being hurt most it's students with student loan debt. The student loan bubble is due to artificially inflated prices because you can get these loans. So that's what's got to be tied. You've got to teach kids that socialism ruins your life. It bankrupted you by artificially inflating the price of college. They can raise the tuition because of there are loans that could cover it. And then you're stuck with it and these greedy administrators are laughing all the way to the bank while you basically mortgage your life. That's socialism.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And you know they've just raised rates -- college rates -- college tuitions in in Vermont.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: At the university where Bernie Sanders' wife works. And also, their daughter taught a woodcutting class there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yep, it costs $383,000.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: To take the course?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: To get the whole -- to get the class all organized.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I want to just end by telling you that a poll asked people if you don't care about the issues but you care who can beat Trump, who's your pick? And 56 percent chose Joe Biden.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What a dumb poll.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We have -- I'll take that to the bank. We have brand-new video reportedly showing the brothers in the Jussie Smollett case buying the materials that were used in the attack. That breaking new development next on “The Five.”

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Fox News alert, major new developments in the Jussie Smollett investigation. Chicago police have announced Smollett is officially a suspect in a criminal investigation for filing a false report.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Meanwhile, stunning new surveillance video obtained by CBS Chicago has surfaced reportedly showing two brothers at the center of the case buying what is believed to be a red hat and ski mask the day before the attack. This as prosecutors in Chicago are meeting with Smollett's lawyers. Mike Tobin, outside criminal court in Chicago with the latest. Mike?

utterances.speaker: MIKE TOBIN, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: this is all happening very fast and furious. You've just mentioned moments ago, the chief communications officer Anthony Guglielmi for the Chicago PD says that Jussie Smollett is now a suspect for a class four felony, falsifying a police report. We know that's a punishable by a maximum of three years. This while we have just learned from people who have been staking out the grand jury room on the fourth floor that the Osundairo brothers have gone back inside for round two inside the grand jury room, seemed to be kind of a false start with the grand jury yesterday. And again, the people who have been staking out the grand jury room say the brothers are inside at this moment as the case moves forward. On a day when we now have surveillance video coming to us from WBBM channel two here in Chicago, and this is security video from what we're told by employees at the Crafty Beaver is inside of their store, and it shows these individuals buying things like ski masks, what looks to be a red hat. We know of the inventory that was taken from the apartment where the Osundairo brothers were staying here in Chicago. One of the items on that inventory is a red hat, and that could have very well played a role in what is now shaping up more and more to have been a hoax attack in this case. So we now have Jussie Smollett, he's been listed as a suspect in this case officially according to the chief communications officer. This long- standing request for police to have a conversation with Smollett, that has not been realized. He never showed up for this follow-up interview. We have some information that lawyers for Smollett and police met today. The Sun Times has indicated that that meeting is going on right now. The clarification we have through the official police channels is that meeting happened this morning but never the conversation that they want to have with Smollett. Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thanks a lot, Mike. All right, Emily, I believe the prosecutors have to go hard on this class four felony. They have to prosecute him. They can't just drop this because if they don't go hard on him, it's going to send a message that you can get away with this stuff and not pay a price.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yeah, absolutely. And you know there's prosecutorial discretion there in Illinois. They could have proceed it as a misdemeanor. They have the option for filling a false police --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They've prompt it up.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Exactly. So that speaks for itself right there. And you know those crimes are classified as they're crimes against public justice. It's taken really seriously because it is. There should absolutely be zero tolerance for and a strong message sent when people do this, especially in the level of fabrication that, you know, we are seeing, allegedly, when into this. That level of pro-action and creating this entire dramatic thing and roping in other people, I mean, it's -- yes, it's absolutely should have dire consequences, for sure.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, Mike Tobin still with us, I think. Mike? Mike, are you there? Well, maybe not.

utterances.speaker: TOBIN
utterances.utterance: I'm here.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, Mike. So, Mike, as I understand it, there was pressure being put to bring Smollett into the grand jury. But today, apparently, his lawyers spoke to the Cook County attorneys and they said OK, he doesn't have to come in. I wonder, is he sick? What was the mitigating factor or the sculpting factor that would lead Cook County officials to say he didn't have to appear before the grand jury?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Because they can do it without him.

utterances.speaker: TOBIN
utterances.utterance: I think it's more of a situation where you have -- you get this with the legal community that any good lawyer, if he's going to insist that he did nothing wrong, any good lawyer is going to tell them don't go in for that meeting because all they're going to want to do in the course of that meeting is catch him in a lie. And all indications are that something is amiss in this case. So I don't know if it's necessary exculpatory evidence that gets involved in that, but when you have this sudden halt to the process yesterday, and the Cook County state attorney Kim Fox, recusing yourself, you may have some kind of evidence that was introduced yesterday. And it should be noted that The Tribune is running a report right now saying the reason she has suddenly recuse herself is because she got pretty close with the family during the initial stages, when everyone thought that Jussie Smollett was the victim of a hate crime.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thanks, Mike. Dana, you know what's crazy about this whole thing and how sociopathic this guy Smollett is? If they had arrested two innocent guys, he would have said, yeah, these are the guys and he would have been OK with putting away innocent men.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Did you watch “The Five” yesterday?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I made that point.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, you did? Great minds think alike, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And also, this is -- I have a question. These guys work in television. They work on a very successful show, Empire. Did they not think that there's not going to be -- like, all of these questions? I just feel like he was willing to put other people away for something that also was like very poorly done.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: As for as the hoax goes, he must have just truly believed that the media was just going to believe every word that he said and then he was going to be protected from that. But I'm glad the police are pursuing it. I think it's good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, great actor, terrible criminal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Bear with me, Juan. I listen to you. This is a hate crime. And to your point, that's despicable that he would let two people go to jail. Remember, us, the people that aren't liberals are vindicated because any kind of tangential link to Trump, you, if you don't believe this story then you are part of the problem. This - everybody should be pleased that a hate crime didn't happen, because it means we're less racist than the media wants us to be. And I don't care about Smollett anymore. He's dirt. I am more pissed off at how the media did this and they've got to pay a price too.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I'm glad to know, it's all about you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No. You missed my point, Juan, but that's usual, that's usual for you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's his excuse.

Also when you said you know he may be mentally ill, I'm not going to speak to that, but to the fact that he has a prior from 2007 in California for false impersonation, DUI, and driving without a valid license when he was pulled over for driving under the influence, he said he was his brother and faked that. Breaking news out of Chicago, police have announced Jussie Smollett is officially a suspect in a criminal investigation for filing a false report. utterances.speaker: MIKE TOBIN, REPORTER
utterances.utterance: And so, there are two big developments that we've got to hear just a short time ago. One as you mentioned that Jussie Smollett is no longer considered a victim. He's no longer in limbo. He is officially a suspect for a class four felony filing a false police report. Maximum penalty we know for that is three years in prison and $25,000 fine. Also, as you mentioned, evidence is being presented to a grand jury on the fourth floor in this building behind me. We know from people who have been staking out the grand jury room that the Osundairo brothers are inside there. So, their testimony is part of the evidence that is being presented to the grand jury. And we're waiting to see what will come out of that grand jury. After this long waiting game that started really Friday night with police saying, they wanted to bring Smollett in for some follow-up questioning. He lawyered up. He got his crisis intervention team. It became clear that they were never going to say no to police that they're coming in for this follow-up questioning. But they weren't coming in. They were just dragging their feet. That was never going to happen. Police eventually ran out of time with that and they're now presenting evidence to the grand jury. We'll see what comes out of the grand jury and if it ultimately results in an arrest warrant. Things are moving pretty fast here in Chicago. Guys.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Emily, if you don't mind. Mike, this is Dana and I had a quick question. Are the Osundairo brothers in any trouble at all or are they just witnesses at this point?

utterances.speaker: TOBIN
utterances.utterance: It says that they were - the police made it very clear that they were released. There has been a lot of reporting to the effect that they didn't cook any kind of an immunity deal. But they have been cooperating with prosecutors and after their initial interrogation, police said, they had evidence to believe that they should go free. Dana.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Mike, is there any suggestion of motive? Why did he do this? Earlier, I was talking with my friends here at “The Five” and I said, maybe this guy is just mentally troubled or something, but it doesn't make sense. Why would someone do something like this?

utterances.speaker: TOBIN
utterances.utterance: You know that's the big question out there. The official channels don't speculate on that at all. You've got to get to this anonymous source type reporting. One of the speculative reports out there that says that he first set this threatening letter to himself, didn't get the response that he wanted. So, he upped the ante with this big staged attack. There were some other reporting to the effect that he was being written out or minimized in the drama, Empire. So, he staged this attack to get some attention, but keep in mind, the 20th Century Fox issued pretty strongly worded statement saying that no not at all. They're still standing behind their actor.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I have an idea guys why he might have done this. So, I think he planned it so that one camera was actually going to capture the attack. So, there was going to be video that would have gone all over the media of guys in red hats, black masks.

utterances.utterance: So, true.

He would have gotten everything he wanted with his album. He would have gotten all the publicity in the world and that one camera was facing the wrong way and he thought the media would buy it. And it was all going to work out. But cops are smarter than that. PD did a very, very good job of breaking this down. The story was almost too big to fail, and the media wasn't asking questions because they didn't want to ask questions, because if it was a hoax, which I think deep down even they knew, it wasn't right. They didn't want to get to the truth, because if it was a lie then that was shame on them too.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: What's so troubling to me about the initial reaction to is the fact that people were vilified literally for.

utterances.utterance: Questioning.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. The far left went after the media for using the word allegedly.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes. And then how does that all factor in now when I'm sure it's going to be a lot of muted tolerance about this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK. I want to answer that question, because I have facts, which is rare.

utterances.utterance: I'm glad you said it.
